abstract.p: St Louis Cardinals defeat Arizona Diamondbacks, 15-5, at Busch Stadium; Mark McGwire hits 3 home runs; other National League scores noted; photo (M)

block.p: CARDINALS 15, DIAMONDBACKS 5
Mark McGwire is right back on track.
McGwire hit three homers last night, breaking an eight-game homerless drought, as the St. Louis Cardinals routed the Arizona Diamondbacks, 15-5.

McGwire, who tied Willie Mays's major league record by homering in the first four games of the season, had not homered since April 4. He has seven homers -- all at Busch Stadium -- and 22 runs batted in.
CARDINALS 15, DIAMONDBACKS 5
Mark McGwire is right back on track.
McGwire hit three homers last night, breaking an eight-game homerless drought, as the St. Louis Cardinals routed the Arizona Diamondbacks, 15-5.

McGwire, who tied Willie Mays's major league record by homering in the first four games of the season, had not homered since April 4. He has seven homers -- all at Busch Stadium -- and 22 runs batted in.

McGwire hit a two-run homer in the third, a solo homer in the fifth and another two-run shot in the eighth, a 462-footer off Barry Manuel. It was his third three-homer game and first since June 11, 1995, for Oakland against Boston.
The last Cardinal to hit three homers in a game was Mark Whiten, who hit four in the second game of a doubleheader at Cincinnati on Sept. 7, 1993.
Matt Williams hit the first grand slam in Arizona's history. The Diamondbacks have lost six straight games and are 1-8 on their first road trip.
Brian Jordan homered and had four r.b.i. for the Cardinals.
BRAVES 6, PIRATES 0
Kevin Millwood, the unsung member of Atlanta's rotation, pitched a one-hitter and had a career-high 13 strikeouts.
The Braves did all of their scoring on three homers, including a three-run shot in the sixth by Andruw Jones, who entered the game hitting .100 with no homers and just one run batted in.
But this night belonged to Millwood (2-0), the 23-year-old fifth starter in Atlanta's rotation who faced only two batters over the minimum and did not walk a batter.
He had at least one strikeout in every inning and did not allow a baserunner until Jermaine Allensworth doubled to left-center on a hanging curve with one out in the fifth.
Pittsburgh's only other baserunner reached in the seventh when Jason Kendall was hit by a pitch.
It was Milwood's first career complete game in his 11th start.
BREWERS 7 EXPOS 4
John Jaha's bases-loaded triple highlighted a five-run second inning, and Scott Karl became the first Milwaukee pitcher to score a run since 1989.
Karl gave up four hits in six and one-third innings, striking out five, and retired his final 11 batters.
Karl singled in the second and came home on Jaha's big hit.
NATIONAL LEAGUE: YESTERDAY
